_prev_prog_3.Description: Anhydrous Ammonia refrigerant system in an industrial closed loop refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Ventura Coastal - Visalia has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Ventura Coastal - Visalia, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Ventura Coastal - Visalia has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                 | Process Chemical             | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration          Anhydrous Ammonia              17,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regu

lation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Description



Facility Layout



Ventura Coastal - Visalia operates a juice processing facility for orange juice and concentrate in Visalia, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:



(1) Blend Room

(1) Packaging Room

(3) Freezers

(2) Shell & Tube Pasteurizers

(2) De-Oilers (North and South)

(5) Plate Heat Exchangers

(23) Jacketed Tanks



Refrigeration System Equipment



In general, the refrigerated rooms, jacketed tanks, and heat exchangers are equipped with evaporators and liquid recirculators for pumped overfeed operation. The Concentrate Chiller, Cold Wall Tanks C-G, and Silo 2 are equipped with accumulators as required for flooded operation

Most control valve groups are located on the roof or in the processing room catwalk to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly above the machinery room. A partial list of system components includes:



Machinery Room

(6) Screw compressors

(6) Oil separators

(1) High pressure receiver

(1) Auto-Purger

(1) Glycol plate and frame heat exchanger



Condenser Area

(4) Evaporative condensers



North of Machinery Room

(3) Recirculators with integral pumps and oil pot



West of Machinery Room

(1) Jacketed silo

(1) Accumulator



Processing Room

(5) Jacketed cold-wall tanks (2 outside)

(5) Accumulators (2 outside)

(1) Plate and frame chiller (fresh)



Tank Farm 1

(1) Flooded concentrate chiller

(2) Rooftop penthouse units



Packaging Room

(4) Jacketed blend tanks

(2) Rooftop penthouse units

Tank Farm 2

(2) Rooftop penthouse units

(1) Loadout chiller



0?F Freezer

(2) Rooftop penthouse units



North Processing Room

(4) Jacketed blend tanks

(1) Rooftop penthouse unit



East of Processing Room

(2) De-Oilers 



East of North Processing Room (Outside)

(5) Jacketed silos

(2) Pasteurizer shells 

(1) Plate and frame chiller



Process Chemistry



In general, the refrigerated rooms, jacketed tanks, and heat exchangers are equipped with evaporators and liquid recirculators for pumped overfeed operation. The Concentrate Chiller, Cold Wall Tanks C-G, and Silo 2 are equipped with accumulators as required for flooded operation. In this system, high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to the liquid recirculators, ceiling-suspended evaporators, and some jacketed storage tanks, heat exchangers, and accumulators. The liquid recirculators are equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the liquid recirculators. Low pressure liquid is pumped from the liquid recirculators to the penthouse evaporators, and various jacketed storage tanks and heat exchangers located throughout the facility. 



The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporator uses an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. In the jacketed storage tanks, the low temperature liquid is pumped into piping within the tank that extends around the tank wall. In the plate and frame heat exchangers, the low temperature liquid flows through channels in the plates and absorbs the heat from the product on the opposite side of each plate. In the shell and tube heat exchanger, the low pressure liquid enters the vesse

istration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Ventura Coastal - Visalia has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Ventura Coastal - Visalia continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Ventura Coastal - Visalia's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Ventura Coastal - Visalia's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Ventura Coastal - Visalia has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance a

l shell and absorbs heat from the product piped through the interior of the heat exchanger. As the liquid ammonia absorbs heat from the product or air, it evaporates to form low temperature and pressure vapor and returns to the liquid recirculators. From the liquid recirculators, the remaining low pressure vapor is piped to the suction inlet on the screw compressors.



The system also includes direct expansion (DX) ceiling suspended evaporator coils. In DX evaporators, high pressure liquid is supplied from the high pressure receiver directly to the evaporators. Each evaporator is equipped with an expansion valve which reduces the pressure and temperature of the liquid as it enters the evaporators. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it exits the evaporators and is returned to the main suction accumulator.



The compressors compress the low pressure vapor, and it exits through the discharge outlet as a high pressure and high temperature vapor. The vapor is then sent to evaporative condensers where it is cooled and liquefied. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within each condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver. The receiver serves as a holding tank for the liquid refrigerant being fed to the low side, and holds the bulk of the refrigerant in the system when it is not operating. 



Safety Systems



At an ammonia concentration of 25 ppm, an alarm is activated on the PLC, and necessary personnel are automatically notified via email. At 50 ppm, the muster system is activated which includes activating a blue light (blue indicates ammonia) inside the production rooms. Additionally, the muster system will activate audible alarms plant-wide at 50 ppm. At an ammonia concentration inside the machinery room exceeding 150 ppm, the compressors are automatica

lly shut down. The compressors are also shut down in the event that a sensor located in a production area reaches 80 ppm. 



The machinery room is equipped with two (2) roof-mounted emergency ventilation fans. The emergency ventilation system can be controlled manually by the HAND/OFF/AUTO switches or the emergency break glass switches outside each machinery room door.



Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. All ASME vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves. The high side of each system relieves at either 250 or 300 psig while the low side of each system relieves at 150 or 250 psig. All pressure relief valves vent to the atmosphere.

Each recirculator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressor.



The Emergency Pressure Control System (EPCS) operates as follows: 

- EPCS is activated at not greater than 90% pressure relief valve setting (e.g. 270 psig or less) [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.3] 

- Upon activation, all compressors are stopped by a means that is independent of all other safety controls [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.6] 

- Upon activation, cross-over valve is opened [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.6] 

- Upon activation, a signal is provided to personnel responsible for refrigeration system maintenance [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.7] 

- EPCS remains active until manually reset [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.8]

- EPCS crossover isolation valves are locked open [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.4.2] 

- The emergency pressure control system is seldom used in a refrigeration system, but has been installed for rare emergency situations.



Process Classification



The ammonia refrigeration system at Ventura Coastal - Visalia consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration

system at Ventura Coastal - Visalia is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss 

preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Ventura Coastal - Visalia has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Ventura Coastal - Visalia facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 17,000 (LBS). It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Ventura Coastal - Visalia has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Ventura Coastal - Visalia's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Admin

udit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Ventura Coastal - Visalia has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Ventura Coastal - Visalia now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Ventura Coastal - Visalia employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Ventura Coastal - Visalia will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
